Award.AwardTitle: Coordination and Student Travel for the 2017 National Radio Frequency (RF) Ionospheric Effects Workshop; Denver, Colorado; May 14-17, 2017
Award.AbstractNarration: This is an award to help support travel expenses for ten students to attend the Ionospheric Modification meeting that is scheduled to be held at the University of Colorado at Denver in early May, 2017.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The annual National RF Ionospheric Effects Workshop was held May 14-17, 2017, at the University of Colorado Denver. The focus of the workshop was on the interaction of high-power RF waves from ground-based transmitters with the ionospheric plasma and resultant phenomena such as the generation of ELF waves, ionospheric irregularities, and induced optical emissions. Using funds from this grant, the Geophysical Institute of the University of Alaska Fairbanks provided support for eight students to attend the meeting.

 

The students were able to observe presentations on a variety of topics ranging from campaign planning to scientific results. Results were presented from both the Arecibo Observatory in Puerto Rico and the HARRP facility in Alaska. Both facilities had research campaigns in the previous year and had significant results to present. In addition, scientists from the Air Force Research Lab reported on a chemical release rocket experiment that investigated radio propagation effects of artificial clouds of ionization.

In addition, students were able to take part in planning discussions for the April 2018 HAARP campaign. This is an important part of the experience students gain by attending such workshops. It helps them to understand the factors beyond what they learn in the classroom that are necessary for conducting experimental science.
